Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2007 08:14AM cbl wrote: I had SNB done at the time of my unilateral mastectomy. My breast surgeon didn't really give me a choice (I know I had a choice but at the time it didn't feel that way) but I can't imagine that I would have said no. The difference between having positive or negative nodes changes your treatment. I had a total of 8 nodes removed - all were NEGATIVE and I have had no pain or side effects related to the SNB. I do treat that arm differently in terms of preventing lymphadema - no injections and blood pressure readings on that side. I would do the same even if I didn't have the SNB. Knowing that there was no node involvement meant that no further treatment (chemo or radiation) was needed and allowed me to proceed with the reconstruction I wanted.

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2007 08:55AM - edited Oct 2, 2007 08:56AM by cbl I had my unilateral tram 14 months ago and I am really very pleased.  I was in the hospital for just 2 nights.  I went home with 3 drains and the On-Q pain ball but everything was removed 4 days later.  I was on oral pain medication for about a week.  The pain meds definitely make you constipated so if you can take something to prevent or ease it you should.  You might also want something to make sure you sleep.  You will heal much better if you sleep well.  I  took ambien for about 2 weeks after my surgery and it was like a miracle. I slept in my own bed but with a lot of pillows.  I don't drive much so that was not an issue for me but I could have driven after about 10 days if I wanted and needed to.  Standing up straight was the most difficult.  I did the  excercises i was given after the mastectomy and regained my range of motion and mobility very quickly but standing and walking were much harder than I anticpated.  Every day things got a little easier and after 6 weeks I was back to "normal" but there were times when I didn't think I would ever be straight.  I have not lost any abdominal strength - in fact I am more motivated to excercise because of my flat belly so I probably have better abs than before.  All in all, it is a long surgery and a long recovery but I am very glad it was what I chose. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2007 12:43PM cbl wrote: I am glad that you are feeling better and that your pathology report was good.  When I had my mastectomy in Aug 2006, I waited until after the full pathology was complete before going on with my reconstruction.  My ps did insert an expander as a "place holder" at the time of the first surgery but my actual reconstruction surgery (tram) was scheduled for several weeks afterward.  This gave me plenty of time to get the patholgoy report back. Thankfully the mastectomy removed everything and I needed no additional therapy so my reconstruction went as planned with no delays or complications.  For me the second surgery was easier because I was less nervous.  I had already begun the recovery process and had full range of motion in my arms.  I knew what drains would look and feel like and I had some indication how bad I would feel.  that doesn't mean everything was wonderful...the pain was much worse for the reconstruction, the surgery was longer and the anesthesia made me sick, the pain was definitely worse and I was generally more uncomfortable physically but emotionally I was in much better shape and I think that had a lot to do with how well and how quickly I healed.  Don't let the worry put you off.
